P. file
October 20, 1927.
My dear General:
div1.p:
Last week Colonel Albert E. Truby came into
the office and we talked about the early work of yellow
fever. Truby tells me that he was on duty in Havana dur-
ing the period in which Reed did his work, and that he
has first-hand knowledge of the various steps which were
taken by Reed and others in yellow fever investigations.
I suggested to Truby that he write up the whole thing
in detail in order to have his recollection of the entire
matter on file in the S.G.O. I did not discuss with him
specifically the matter of publication. I thought that
might depend on what he writes up.

I am writing to you because it seemed to me that
you might be able to stimulate Truby to write up this very
important bit of history better than anyone else. I shall,
I hope, see Truby again from time to time and will urge him
to make a report covering his knowledge of Reed's studies.

I tried to locate Professor Vincent in reply to your
telegram to me of the 4th of October. I sent a telegram to
Vincent at the Biltmore Hotel where he was reported to be staying,
but on the 15th the telegram was returned to me undelivered.
General Jefferson R. Kean
-2-
October 20, 1927
I have not been able to find out just where these men are.
I am sorry I was not able to locate Vincent for you.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, F. F. Russell General Jefferson R. Kean
Army Medical Museum & Library
Seventh and B Streets
Washington, D.C.
